key_title: Key to the subspecies of Olearia phlogopappa

source.author: Messina, A.; Walsh, N.G.; Hoebee, S.E.; Green, P.T.
source.title: A morphological assessment of the Olearia phlogopappa complex (Asteraceae: Astereae).
source.citation: Modified from: Messina, A.; Walsh, N.G.; Hoebee, S.E.; Green, P.T. (2013). A morphological assessment of the Olearia phlogopappa complex (Asteraceae: Astereae).. Australian Systematic Botany 26:31-81.

leads.lead_text: Leaves thin-textured, narrow-lanceolate to narrow-linear, more than seven times as long as wide, with numerous sessile glands on both surfaces; margins entire; west of Melbourne

Leaves moderately to thickly textured, shape various, glands present or absent, usually less than seven times as long as wide or leaves lobed if more than seven times as long as wide; coastal to alpine areas in eastern Victoria
Leaves lanceolate to ovate (widest below the middle); sessile glands usually clearly visible on the lower leaf surface; margins usually crenate; montane and foothill forest

Leaves thick-textured, oblong to obovate (widest at or above the middle), rarely ovate or lanceolate; sessile glands absent or completely obscured by dense hair on the lower leaf surface; margins entire, subentire or crenulate, rarely serrate; subalpine, alpine and coastal areas
Leaves serrate, 1–2.3 cm long; petiole less than 2.5 mm long; rare, alpine and subalpine areas
Leaves shallowly lobed or entire, or if serrate then leaves more than 2.5 cm long; petiole 2–5(–8) mm long; alpine subalpine or coastal areas
Leaves usually entire or subentire; capitula usually in terminal corymbs; alpine and subalpine areas
Leaves crenulate to crenate or serrate; capitula usually in panicles; coastal areas
Leaves ovate to lanceolate, 11–30 mm wide; upper surface soon glabrous; lower surface yellow; restricted to granite outcrops of Wilsons Promontory

Leaves obovate, oblong or narrow elliptic, 3–10(–15) ; upper surface usually retaining a moderate cover of stellate hair; lower surface usually cream-coloured below (sometimes yellowish when young); generally in deep sands on coastal dunes
